Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Spatial Organization Within A Traditional Political System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Marcello Canuto and Maxime Lamoureux-St-Hilaire of Tulane University, along with colleagues from the United States and Guatemala, will undertake research to study Classic Maya royal courts (AD 250-830). This research will focus on the Classic Maya polity of La Corona, located in northern Guatemala. This archaeological project will study the elusive topic of the administrative and economic behaviors which supported the political activities of a royal court for centuries. This project departs from others which have emphasized priestly kings and divine kingship as the focus of Classic Maya political activities because it focusses on the practical dimensions of power. The study of the everyday practicalities of ruling in Classic Maya society will help develop a more pragmatic model for the roles of both the elite and non-elite in the operation of an ancient political institution. While the Classic Maya were unique in many ways, their political institutions were functionally similar to that of other ancient complex societies. Thus, this project's approach is replicable and therefore should positively impact the broader field of anthropological archaeology. Moreover, by broadening our analytical scope, the study of ancient non-western political systems should shed light on studies of modern-day political and economic systems many of which derive from and incorporate such traditional elements.

Dr. Marcello Canuto, Maxime Lamoureux-St-Hilaire, and their research team will study key administrative buildings as well as the floors and refuse-disposal areas associated with the support-oriented section of the La Corona regal palace. Beyond traditional archaeological methods, this research project will employ proven interdisciplinary methods in order to reconstruct the economic behaviors of this ancient institution. Geochemical analyses will study trace-elements absorbed in the plastered floors of the palace, while soil flotation will be used to recover micro-artifacts embedded in those same floors, along with botanical remains recovered from refuse-disposal areas produced by this ancient royal court. These different techniques have only been recently applied jointly to study ancient architecture. The data produced by these interdisciplinary techniques are unique in that they will document several subtle markers of ancient behaviors which would not normally be recoverable by traditional archaeological techniques. The development of this innovative methodology to study the practical aspects of ancient political institutions may positively impact the broader field of anthropological archaeology. This project is part of the larger La Corona Regional Archaeological Project (PRALC), which operates in the northwest Pet√©n Region of Guatemala; one of the most under-studied regions of the Maya world. Moreover, the enduring presence of PRALC helps protect the natural and cultural patrimony of this remote region of Guatemala from human depredation such as poaching, looting, and illegal settlement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this award aimed at understanding the organization of the economic, administrative, ceremonial, and domestic activities that took place at the Late to Terminal Classic Maya royal court of La Corona, Guatemala (A.D. 600-900). This award supported two months of archaeological fieldwork and two sets of laboratory analyses aimed at recovering subtle archaeological traces, that is, micro-artifacts, small botanical remains, and chemical traces in plaster floors. The sponsored research was part of the La Corona Regional Archaeological Project which is co-directed by Dr. Marcello Canuto (Tulane University) and Dr. Tomás Barrientos (Universidad del Valle de Guatemala).

The archaeological investigation supported by this award took place in the monumental palace of La Corona, where four architectural structures, two platforms, three patios, and a refuse disposal areas were investigated. These investigations documented the architecture of the palace and revealed a great deal of information about the material culture of this ancient political institution, which was divided in two distinct architectural groups.

The first group was a courtyard surrounded by vaulted masonry buildings decorated with painted stucco that had domestic, administrative, and ceremonial functions. Under the auspices of this grant, a throne room, a hieroglyphic staircase, along with a large administrative building were excavated in this group. This elaborate architectural complex was connected – through a tightly controlled passageway – to a second, less striking group featuring a mix of sturdy masonry buildings and perishable structures. This latter group, subdivided in three patios, had a distinct set of economic and administrative functions given that it consisted of residences, a kitchen, storage rooms, and patios where many economic activities took place. Additionally, five waste disposal areas were identified in this group – documenting many activities ranging from food preparation and feasting to figurine manufacture. These two architectural groups played different roles, all articulated along a logical order of resource accumulation, transformation, deployment, and discard.

Since the economic activities that took place in the second group did not leave obvious traces, we conducted an extensive sampling program in the three patios, associated midden areas, and inside buildings. We sampled 328 sq. m. from the preserved stucco floors of these different areas and exported the samples to the University of South Florida where they have undergone Inductively-Coupled Plasma Mass-Spectrometry analysis by Dr. Christian Wells. Additionally, we took 214 1L soil samples from the three patios and 24 3L soil samples from the midden areas. These soil samples underwent flotation and microscope-assisted macro-botanical analysis in Guatemala City by Dr. Clarissa Cagnato. Once all the results from these analyses are organized, they will be rendered comprehensively in a set of maps, which will be done before April 2017.

This research has provided a new perspective on Classic Maya royal courts by focussing on the practicalities of the everyday life of the ruling elite and on the complex set of economic behaviors necessary to support it. By reaching to complementary scientific methods outside of archaeology, this research has also proposed a set of methods that are replicable and may positively influence the field of anthropological archaeology. Additionally, this research project contributed to hiring a dozen of local workers and several professional archaeologist. Additionally, this international collaborative effort, spearheaded by an American institution, contributed to the development of an integrated scientific community. Preliminary results of this research have already been presented in Guatemala, Europe, and the United States, and the results will continue to be disseminated through professional and public presentations over the next years. A formal research report has already been written and several publications are planned in order to present the results to the scientific community over the next few years.
